sub_topic: Solving nonlinear equations using Newton-Raphson method
message_1: Find the root of the equation f(x) = x^3 - 2x - 5 using the Newton-Raphson method with an initial guess of x=2, rounded to 4 decimal places.
message_2:
To use the Newton-Raphson method, we first need to find the derivative of the function f(x) = x^3 - 2x - 5. The derivative, f'(x), is:

f'(x) = 3x^2 - 2

Now, we will apply the Newton-Raphson formula:

x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0)

where x0 is the initial guess (x=2) and x1 is the updated guess.

f(x0) = (2)^3 - 2(2) - 5 = 8 - 4 - 5 = -1
f'(x0) = 3(2)^2 - 2 = 12 - 2 = 10

x1 = 2 - (-1) / 10 = 2 + 0.1 = 2.1

Now, we will repeat the process until we reach the desired precision (4 decimal places). We will use x1 as the new guess (x0) and calculate x2:

f(x1) = (2.1)^3 - 2(2.1) - 5 ≈ -0.389
f'(x1) = 3(2.1)^2 - 2 ≈ 10.83

x2 = 2.1 - (-0.389) / 10.83 ≈ 2.1359

We can continue this process, but since we are asked to round to 4 decimal places, we can stop here. The root of the equation f(x) = x^3 - 2x - 5 using the Newton-Raphson method with an initial guess of x=2 is approximately x ≈ 2.1359.
